column1: Bill Bryson's African Diary, The Lost Continent, Neither Here nor There, The Life and Times of the Thunderbolt Kid, A Walk in the Woods, I'm a Stranger Here Myself, In a Sunburned Country, Notes from a Big Country, The Mother Tongue, Made in America, A Short History of Nearly Everything, The Body, At Home, One Summer, Shakespeare, The Road to Little Dribbling, Down Under, A History of Britain, The English and Their History, The Land of Hope and Glory, Notes from a Small Island
column2:
Suddenly, in the space of a moment, I realized what it was that I loved about Britain-which is to say, all of it.

After nearly two decades spent on British soil, Bill Bryson - bestselling author of The Mother Tongue and Made in America-decided to return to the United States. (I had recently read, Bryson writes, that 3.7 million Americans believed that they had been abducted by aliens at one time or another, so it was clear that my people needed me.) But before departing, he set out on a grand farewell tour of the green and kindly island that had so long been his home.

Veering from the ludicrous to the endearing and back again, Notes from a Small Island is a delightfully irreverent jaunt around the unparalleled floating nation that has produced zebra crossings, Shakespeare, Twiggie Winkie's Farm, and places with names like Farleigh Wallop and Titsey. The result is an uproarious social commentary that conveys the true glory of Britain, from the satiric pen of an unapologetic Anglophile.

column1: Cheaper by the Dozen, Belles on Their Toes, Who Gets the Drumstick, Please Don't Eat the Daisies, Life with Father, Father of the Bride, The Beverly Hillbillies, I Love Lucy, The Honeymooners, The Andy Griffith Show, The Dick Van Dyke Show, The Brady Bunch, The Partridge Family, The Waltons, Little House on the Prairie, Eight is Enough, Family Affair, The Donna Reed Show, Please Don't Eat the Daisies, Cheaper by the Dozen
column2:
Adapted into two classic motion pictures, this bestselling memoir is the unforgettable story of two parents, twelve kids, and a world of laughter and love.

Translated into more than fifty languages, Cheaper by the Dozen is the unforgettable story of the Gilbreth clan as told by two of its members. In this endearing, amusing memoir, siblings Frank Jr. and Ernestine capture the hilarity and heart of growing up in an oversized family.

Mother and Dad are world-renowned efficiency experts, helping factories fine-tune their assembly lines for maximum output at minimum cost. At home, the Gilbreths themselves have cranked out twelve kids, and Dad is out to prove that efficiency principles can apply to family as well as the workplace.

The heartwarming and comic stories of the jumbo-size Gilbreth clan have delighted generations of readers, and will keep you and yours laughing for years.

column1: Pride and Prejudice, Jane Eyre, Wuthering Heights, Sense and Sensibility, Emma, Northanger Abbey, Mansfield Park, Persuasion, Vanity Fair, The Tenant of Wildfell Hall, The Mill on the Floss, Middlemarch, The Small House at Allington, The Eustace Diamonds, The Warden, Barchester Towers, The Last Chronicle of Barset, Can You Forgive Her, The Prime Minister, Gentleman Prefer Blondes, The Malory Novels, Gentleman Prefer Blondes
column2:
Left penniless and in dire straits, Kelsey Langton realizes that only by allowing herself to be sold at auction can she rescue her sister's future. So the proud, desperate lady enters the infamous House of Eros, resigned to becoming some well-heeled gentleman's plaything -- and Lord Derek Malory is the highest bidder for Kelsey's charms.

A handsome and irredeemable scoundrel, Derek soon draws the sensuous, unsuspecting maiden into a world of unparalleled pleasures and dangerous rivalries. But Kelsey knows she must always guard the secret of her highborn past -- even as her grace, spirit, and beauty entice her new master to renounce his scandalous ways and take a gamble on true love.
